                Hillary Clinton, her presidential campaign chairman John Podesta, left, and Deputy Chief of Staff of Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid David McCallum on Capitol Hill. | Getty

            By 
Lauren French

11/17/15 11:43 AM EST
Hillary Clinton's top deputy will be on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to continue the campaign's outreach to African-American Democrats. 
John Podesta, the chairman of Clinton's presidential campaign, will be at the Democratic National Committee headquarters to discuss their strategy and talk to members of the Congressional Black Caucus.
Story Continued Below
The Clinton campaign has been heavily courting members of the black caucus — a group that strongly supported her 2008 primary opponent, then-Sen. Barack Obama — since she first announced her candidacy earlier this year. 
African-American lawmakers have stumped for her on the campaign trail in key early-voting states and in black churches in the South. Clinton also personally hosted a private reception for black lawmakers in September during the Congressional Black Caucus Foundation’s annual gala in Washington.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Clinton campaign continues outreach to black lawmakers
